subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized Test Case example

messageBody:
On Nov 20, 2003, at 4:50 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Mike Clark wrote:
>
>> I'm guessing it has something to do with not wanting to create a
>> BiographicalReport instance on every test method.
>
> Well, you can't avoid that anyway. Each invocation of runTest() occurs
> in its own instance of TestCase.
>


Then my guess was wrong. :-)


>> At any rate, it
>> seems to be reaching fairly deep in the trick bag and I'm wondering
>> what I'm missing with the obvious approach.
>
> I avoid this constructor:
>
> public CalculateAgeTest(String testName, int expectedAge,
> Date futureDate) {
>
> super("testCalculateAge"); <<<<<
> this.expectedAge = expectedAge;
> this.futureDate = futureDate;
> }
>
> Also with the "obvious" approach, I can't tell one test from another:
> all the test names look the same. Which one failed?


The one that fails with "expected 10 but was 20"?


> By making the test name different from the test method name, I can use
> the test name to report specifically which line of data led to a
> failing
> test.

Understood.

I agree that this solution works well when you want to externalize the
data for a data-driven solution. I guess externalizing data is my last
resort. I start with individual test case methods with common code
refactored into a custom assertion. I start there partly because it's
easier for me to see the data and the assertion side by side in a test
method. And I name the test methods according to why the specific
piece of data is important to test. So if a test fails, I know by
looking at the method name what went wrong.

Rarely do I find that I have enough permutations of data to justify
externalizing the data. But when that does happen, I externalize it.
Even in that case I don't use a parameterized test case.

I've seen the parameterized test case used. I've never had occasion to
use it myself. Perhaps it's my testing style. I'm using this as an
opportunity to question why I don't use parameterized test case, not as
an opportunity to caution you not to use it.

Mike
